Welcome to parser_pro’s documentation!

examples

examples package

Subpackages

examples.operator package
Submodules
examples.operator.plus module

Examples :

>>> data = {
    "hobbies": ["Reading", "Hiking", "Travelling"],
    "age": "30",
    "marks": "34",
    "nums": [1, 2, 3, 4]
}
>>> expr = "hobbies + hobbies"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"['Reading', 'Hiking', 'Travelling', 'Reading', 'Hiking', 'Travelling']"

>>> data = {
    "hobbies": ["Reading", "Hiking", "Travelling"],
    "age": "30",
    "marks": "34",
    "nums": [1, 2, 3, 4]
}
>>> expr = "age + marks"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"3034"

>>> data = {
    "hobbies": ["Reading", "Hiking", "Travelling"],
    "age": "30",
    "marks": "34",
    "nums": [1, 2, 3, 4]
}
>>> expr = "nums[1] + nums[3]"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"6"

>>> data = {
    "hobbies": ["Reading", "Hiking", "Travelling"],
    "age": "30",
    "marks": "34",
    "nums": [1, 2, 3, 4]
}
>>> expr = '"he is " + age + " but still he got " + marks + " marks"'
>>> parse(data, expr)
"he is 30 but still he got 34 marks"
Module contents
examples.queries package
Submodules
examples.queries.get module

Examples :

>>> data = "parser-pro"
>>> expr = '$get("2","7")'
>>> parse(data, expr)
"rser-"

>>> data = ["parser", "pro"]
>>> expr = "$get('0')"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"parser"

>>> data = ["parser", "pro", "v", "1.0"]
>>> expr = "$get('1', '3')"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"['pro', 'v']"
examples.queries.select module

Examples :

>>> data = {"name": "parser", "postfix": "v-0.1"}
>>> expr = '$select("name","postfix")'
>>> parse(data, expr)
"{'name': 'parser', 'postfix': 'v-0.1'}"
Module contents
examples.string_manipulation package
Submodules
examples.string_manipulation.methods module

Examples :

>>> data = {"name": "parser-pro", "address": {"street": "random"}, "nums": [1, 2, 3, 4]}
>>> expr = "address.street | $split("e")"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"['random']"

>>> data = [1, 2, 3, 4]
>>> expr = "$join('|')"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"1|2|3|4"

>>> data = "parser-pro-v.1"
>>> expr = '$replace("v.1", "v.2")'
>>> parse(data, expr)
"parser-pro-v.2"

>>> data = "parser-pro"
>>> expr = '$split("-")'
>>> parse(data, expr)
"['parser', 'pro']"
Module contents

Submodules

examples.Importing_module module

>>> from parser_pro import parse

examples.basic_usage module

Examples :

>>> data = {"name": "parser-pro", "address": {"street": "random"}, "nums": [1, 2, 3, 4]}
>>> expr = "address.street"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"random"

>>> data = {"name": "parser-pro", "address": {"street": "random"}, "nums": [1, 2, 3, 4]}
>>> expr = "nums[1]"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"2"

>>> data = {"name": "parser-pro", "address": {"street": "random"}, "nums": [1, 2, 3, 4]}
>>> expr = "nums"
>>> parse(data, expr)
"[1, 2, 3, 4]"

examples.map module

Examples :

>>> data = [1, 2, 3, 4]
>>> expr = '$map_list({"key":".value"})'
>>> parse(data, expr)
"[{"key":"1"},{"key":"2"},{"key":"3"},{"key":"4"}]"

>>> data = {"name": "parser-pro"}
>>> expr = '$map_dict({"key-.key":".value"})'
>>> parse(data, expr)
"[{"key-name":"parser-pro"}]"

parser_pro.json_handler package
Submodules
parser_pro.json_handler.parser module
parser_pro.json_handler.parser.parse(json_data: dict, path: str)

function used to parse complex python objects using “.” operator for nested dict and [i] for lists where i is index of list

Module contents
parser_pro.lexer package
Submodules
parser_pro.lexer.methods_args module
parser_pro.lexer.methods_args.extract_method_and_args(input_string: str) → list

” function used to extract method name and arguments string from lexer generated token

parser_pro.lexer.operator module
parser_pro.lexer.operator.extract_operators_and_operands(expression: str, operator_list: list) → tuple

function used to extract operator and operands from lexer generated tokens

parser_pro.lexer.tokens module
parser_pro.lexer.tokens.generate_tokens(input_string: str) → list

functon generates tokens from parser_pro expression. conditions are as follows:

split expression using pipe ‘|’ ignore any pipe ‘|’ written in double quotes as it will be treated as constant

parser_pro.methods package
Subpackages
parser_pro.methods.args_validator package
Submodules
parser_pro.methods.args_validator.is_dict_string module
parser_pro.methods.args_validator.is_dict_string.is_dict_string(arg: str) → bool

function used to validate args of a method and check whether its a valid dict or not

Module contents
parser_pro.methods.dict package
Submodules
parser_pro.methods.dict.map_dict module
parser_pro.methods.dict.map_dict.map_dict(data: dict, args: str)

function implements $map_dict functionality of parser Args:

data: dict args:string containing dict e.g {“name”:”.key”,”place”:”.value”}

.key and .value are used to access the key and value of data

Returns:

list containing dict objects e.g [{},{}]

Module contents
parser_pro.methods.filters package
Submodules
parser_pro.methods.filters.condition module
parser_pro.methods.filters.condition.eq(data: list, args: str)

function implements the $eq functionality of parser Args:

data:dict args: str containing args in double quotes , separated by comma

Returns:

list containing all the objects if key equals to value

Module contents
parser_pro.methods.list package
Submodules
parser_pro.methods.list.join module
parser_pro.methods.list.join.join(data: list, args: str) → str

function implements $join functionality of parser

Args:

data: list of items , where items can be list,tuple,str,int,dict args: str containing substring to join all the items

Returns: single string containing all the joined items

parser_pro.methods.list.map_list module
parser_pro.methods.list.map_list.map_list(data: Any, args: str) → list

function implements $map_list functionality of parser

Args:

data: str , dict, list args: string containing valid python dict.

e.g. {“new_key”:”.value”}

.value is used to access the values of input data

Returns:

list containing all dict objects

Module contents
parser_pro.methods.query package
Submodules
parser_pro.methods.query.get module
parser_pro.methods.query.get.get(data: Any, args: str)

functon implements $get functionality of parser Args:

data: str , list or any data type where index can be applied args: index in double quotes e.g “0”

range of index can be given as “1”,”4”

Returns:

subset of data in given index or range

parser_pro.methods.query.select module
parser_pro.methods.query.select.select(data: dict, args: str)

function implements $select functionality of parser

Args:

data: dict args: str as “,” separated keys , each key written in double quotes

Returns:

new dict object combined the selected keys

Module contents
parser_pro.methods.string package
Submodules
parser_pro.methods.string.replace module
parser_pro.methods.string.replace.replace(data: str, args: str) → str

function implements $replace functionality of parser Args:

data: str args: str as args1 with arg2 where both args should be written in double quotes and seperated by “,”

Returns:

replaced string with arg2 where in place of arg1

parser_pro.methods.string.split module
parser_pro.methods.string.split.split(data: str, args: str)

function implements $split functionality of parser Args:

data: str args: str as args1 with arg2 (optional , used to set number of time string should ve split )

where both args should be written in double quotes and separated by “,”

Returns:

list containing chunks split by arg1

Module contents
Submodules
parser_pro.methods.decorator module
parser_pro.methods.decorator.method(func)

This is a decorator used to implement methods used in parser

Hint:

checks compatibility of input data with method args each implemented method will take 2 args namely ( data , args ). Type of each arg is optional but type hint should be given

Module contents
parser_pro.methods.get_method(name: str)
parser_pro.operators package
Subpackages
parser_pro.operators.operators package
Submodules
parser_pro.operators.operators.add module
parser_pro.operators.operators.add.add(operands: list)

function implements ‘+’ operator functionality in parser

Args:

operands: list of all parsed keys given as operands

Returns:

if args in [int] returns addition of digits if args in [str,tuple,dict,list] concatenated data

Module contents
Submodules
parser_pro.operators.decorator module
parser_pro.operators.decorator.operator(func)

This is decorator used to implement operators each implemented operator function should take only one arg namely args:list

Module contents

Module contents

parser_pro.parse(data: dict, s: str)

function implements the parse function of parser_pro

Args:

data: dict s: string containing parser_pro expression

Returns:

parsed data
